title: Spotted Lanternfly vs. Pennsylvania: The Bug Is Winning
text:
The government sent out a message: Kill them all.

Flamethrowers, chemicals and heavy boots are some weapons of choice.

“Stop. Scrape. Squish,” read one informational poster. Another: “Join the battle. Beat the bug.”

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has declared war on the invasive spotted lanternfly, but southeastern Pennsylvania seems to be losing the fight.

The enemy

Twenty-two counties in Pennsylvania and New Jersey are under quarantine—meaning trucks have to follow special shipping rules—and sightings have been confirmed in Delaware and Virginia. The country-loving insects, originally from India, China and Vietnam, have even recently been spotted in downtown Philadelphia.

“I try and step on them all the time,” said Robin Hyndman, in Allentown, Pa. “This is the second”—pausing to stomp on one—“year they’ve been here.”

Videos on social media reveal scenes on the front lines. In one Instagram post, a man approaches a tree covered with spotted lanternflies. “This is what I’m dealing with,” he says, pointing to the insects. “Somebody has got to die.” He takes a lighter to a spray can and fries the bugs with a burst of flame.

In a post on the “Stop the Spotted Lanternfly” Facebook group, a man shows a 10 foot PVC pipe modified to attach to a vacuum cleaner so it could reach trees: “400 less bugs today!” the poster writes.

Entomologist Heather Leach holds two spotted lanternflies. Photo: Talal Ansari/The Wall Street Journal

Berks County, Pa., is bug ground zero. There are millions of spotted lanternflies in the region—laying eggs in the fall and hatching in early summer. By July, they are fully grown into inch-long adults, spotted on the outside with a flame red patch under the wings. They suck on the sap of trees and excrete a sticky residue called “honeydew”—bad for the trees and the cars parked below them.

Pennsylvania’s agricultural department said the bugs threaten to destroy $18 billion in plant-based commodities in the state.

Richard Blair ’s Setter Ridge Vineyards in Kutztown, Pa., was one of the first places to see the spotted lanternfly in 2014. Back then, it was a trickle. By the summer of 2017, one of Mr. Blair’s two vineyard locations was a total loss.

A fly swatter is now a permanent fixture on a wooden post on the estate’s veranda. “We play a game to see how many we can kill in 60 seconds,” Mr. Blair said.

Twenty miles east in Allentown, a city of 120,000, the newly revitalized downtown is full of people smushing bugs. On a recent afternoon, one man hopped around trying to avoid the dead carcasses on the sidewalk. Another woman swung her body to and fro to avoid the erratic flight of a spotted lanternfly.

Hundreds of dead bugs lay on the ground next to shimmering new buildings, evidence of direct extermination efforts.

“The numbers were astounding,” said Pat Harris, of Enviro-Tech Pest Services, a company hired to combat the infestation around the downtown with pesticide. “We are cleaning up hundreds each day, and sometimes in the thousands.”

In the 2000s, the insect spread across South Korea within three years. The country, which covers about the same area as Pennsylvania, still sees regular outbreaks.

They consistently flummox quarantine efforts by being able to lay eggs on almost any surface and move long distances on infested materials. The USDA has declared them “hitchhiking pests.”

Heather Leach, an entomologist with Penn State University who specializes in the spotted lanternfly, is part of a 150-person effort by the U.S. and Pennsylvania Departments of Agriculture and Penn State to study the bug and ultimately, they hope, control its spread.

Ms. Leach has seen all types of ways to kill the insects: guns that shoot grains of salt, bonfires, bleach, kerosene, WD-40. “It just seems like no matter what we do, they keep coming,” she said.

None of those methods are endorsed by agricultural authorities or the experts at Penn State. Officials there are still looking for the best way to eradicate the problem—including an indigenous fungus that would be sprayed in the area.

Some locals are making the best of a messy situation. Artist Elsabé J. Dixon is working on an installment composed almost entirely of dead spotted lanternflies, funded by a grant from Penn State Lehigh Valley and the affected communities.

Art by Elsabé J. Dixon uses the wings of spotted lanternflies. Photo: Amy Gery/Penn State Lehigh Valley

For the piece, Ms. Dixon is affixing the bug’s red and black wings in six circles. She estimates the smallest of the six circles in the art piece, measuring just one foot in diameter, contains as many as 5,000 wings.

“It is almost a superbug,” she said. “It’s moving and spreading like wildfire.”

Julie Foster, the co-owner of Tired Hands Brewing Company in Ardmore, Pa., began selling Spotted Lanternfly IPA in 2018 to raise awareness of the species. Although she admires the insect’s beauty, Ms. Foster said she has used a blowtorch to “great effect.”

“I killed so many last summer that when I closed my eyes some nights, all I could see was the lanternflies,” Ms. Foster said.

A scoreboard showed how many spotted lanternflies the employees of Molly’s Irish Grille & Sports Pub in Bethlehem, Pa., have killed. Below, bartender Madison-Maya Nagai kills a bug in the parking lot behind the bar. Photo: Talal Ansari/The Wall Street Journal

Photo: Talal Ansari/The Wall Street Journal

The co-workers at Molly’s Irish Grille & Sports Pub in Bethlehem, Pa., keep a scoreboard with the number of spotted lanternflies they have killed. “We just do it for bragging rights,” said Madison-Maya Nagai.

The bar created a shot in honor of the pesky insect, made of Patron XO, grenadine and whipped cream. It’s topped with two candy eyeballs. Asked if the shot tastes good, Ms. Nagai said, “No. But it’s not supposed to because the lanternflies suck, too.”

Write to Talal Ansari at Talal.Ansari@wsj.com
description: Grossed-out residents resort to flamethrowers and giant vacuums but the pest just keeps coming. “Stop. Scrape. Squish.”
